articles.headline: Ratings Shrink President’s List for Judgeships
articles.snippet: The American Bar Association has declared a significant number of President Obama’s judicial prospects “not qualified,” slowing White House efforts to fill vacancies.
articles.abstract: The American Bar Association has declared a significant number of President Obama’s judicial prospects “not qualified,” slowing White House efforts to fill vacancies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American Bar Association has secretly declared a significant number of President Obama’s potential judicial nominees “not qualified,” slowing White House efforts to fill vacant judgeships — and nearly all of the prospects given poor ratings were women or members of a minority group, according to interviews.

articles.headline: Europe’s Banks Relying on Money From E.C.B.
articles.snippet: Banks clamored for emergency funds from the European Central Bank on Tuesday, borrowing the most since mid-2009, in a sign of the toll of the crisis.
articles.abstract: Banks clamored for emergency funds from the European Central Bank on Tuesday, borrowing the most since mid-2009, in a sign of the toll of the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Banks clamored for emergency funds from the European Central Bank on Tuesday, borrowing the most since early 2009 in a clear sign that the euro region’s financial institutions are having trouble obtaining credit at reasonable rates on the open market.

articles.headline: Merck to Pay $950 Million Over Vioxx
articles.snippet: Merck has pleaded guilty to a criminal charge over the marketing and sales of the painkiller Vioxx.
articles.abstract: Merck has pleaded guilty to a criminal charge over the marketing and sales of the painkiller Vioxx.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merck has agreed to pay $950 million and has pleaded guilty to a criminal charge over the marketing and sales of the painkiller Vioxx, the company and the Justice Department said Tuesday.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Seeks Review of AT&T Merger With T-Mobile
articles.snippet: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission will request an administrative hearing on the proposed $39 billion acquisition.
articles.abstract: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission will request an administrative hearing on the proposed $39 billion acquisition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission took steps Tuesday to block the proposed $39 billion merger of the mobile phone companies AT&T and T-Mobile USA.

articles.headline: The Old Order Stifles the Birth of a New Egypt
articles.snippet: No groups in Egypt seem prepared to guide the transition to civilian rule because the old order co-opted, eviscerated or abolished the institutions that could have done so.
articles.abstract: No groups in Egypt seem prepared to guide the transition to civilian rule because the old order co-opted, eviscerated or abolished the institutions that could have done so.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — If the demonstrations that culminated in February were an uprising against President Hosni Mubarak, the revolt today is against his legacy.

articles.headline: Fate of Euro May Hinge on Italian Savers
articles.snippet: Italy has been able to rely on the large amount of government debt held by citizens, but financial officials have become fearful that Italians will begin sending their savings abroad.
articles.abstract: Italy has been able to rely on the large amount of government debt held by citizens, but financial officials have become fearful that Italians will begin sending their savings abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even though Europe’s debt crisis has turned Rome into financial ground zero, Italy has been able to lean on at least one solid support: the relatively large amount of government debt held by Italians themselves.

articles.headline: Financial Finger-Pointing Turns to Regulators
articles.snippet: In the whodunit of the financial crisis, the latest defense, surfacing in a fraud case filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is that federal regulators are to blame.
articles.abstract: In the whodunit of the financial crisis, the latest defense, surfacing in a fraud case filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is that federal regulators are to blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the whodunit of the financial crisis, Wall Street executives have pointed the blame at all kinds of parties — consumers who lied on their mortgage applications, investors who demanded access to risky mortgage bonds, and policy makers who kept interest rates low and failed to predict a housing market collapse.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Who’s on the Line? Increasingly, Caller ID Is Duped
articles.snippet: Regulators are hearing more complaints about “caller ID spoofing” or “call laundering” by telemarketers.
articles.abstract: Regulators are hearing more complaints about “caller ID spoofing” or “call laundering” by telemarketers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Caller ID has been celebrated as a defense against unwelcome phone pitches. But it is backfiring.

articles.headline: Republican Might Quit Labor Board
articles.snippet: Brian E. Hayes has threatened to resign in order to block a plan by the National Labor Relations Board to adopt rules that would speed up unionization elections.
articles.abstract: Brian E. Hayes has threatened to resign in order to block a plan by the National Labor Relations Board to adopt rules that would speed up unionization elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board, the subject of particularly intense partisan sniping this year, could soon be completely paralyzed.

articles.headline: Chaos Builds in the Streets of Cairo as a Truce Fails
articles.snippet: The outskirts of Tahrir Square plunged into chaos after attempts by Egypt’s military, religious clerics and doctors failed to stanch a fifth day of fighting.
articles.abstract: The outskirts of Tahrir Square plunged into chaos after attempts by Egypt’s military, religious clerics and doctors failed to stanch a fifth day of fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The outskirts of Tahrir Square, the iconic landmark of Egypt’s revolution, plunged into chaos on Wednesday, after attempts by the Egyptian military, religious clerics and doctors failed to stanch a fifth day of fighting that has posed the greatest crisis to the country since the fall of President Hosni Mubarak in February.

articles.headline: Yemen’s Leader Agrees to End 3-Decade Rule
articles.snippet: If the agreement holds up, President Ali Abdullah Saleh would be the fourth leader forced from power this year by popular uprisings that have shaken the Middle East and North Africa.
articles.abstract: If the agreement holds up, President Ali Abdullah Saleh would be the fourth leader forced from power this year by popular uprisings that have shaken the Middle East and North Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — After more than three decades of autocratic rule, President Ali Abdullah Saleh signed an agreement on Wednesday that immediately transferred power to his vice president, bowing to unrelenting street protests and raising hopes for an end to a political crisis that brought this impoverished nation to the brink of collapse.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Laura Kasinof
